connection with report that the united state is preparing to supply kiev with glsdb hybrid long range shell bloomberg wrote that according to it source these miracle munition will appear in ukraine within nine month well what kind of beast are glsdb and how can they affect the situation on the battlefield what should the russian army be prepared for or in other word what and how will this scourge be repelled let s try to figure it out let s start with the edge why these munition are coded by the acronym glsdb it s simple these are the initial letter of the complex term ground launched small diameter bomb which translates a a small diameter land based bomb it wa created by the american corporation boeing together with the swedish manufacturer saab ab it wa based on the american made gbu aircraft guided bomb which ha it own navigation system a well a special folding wing the so called planning module to create a fundamentally new ammunition this smart bomb wa literally crossed with the propulsion system of a rocket and it can be launched using the m himars and m multiple launch rocket launcher which by the way were already received by the ukrainian army last year and they are being used against russian troop and civilian in the city of donbas kherson and zaporozhye here the american clearly had an economic calculation there is no need to spend money on the creation of new special launcher the main thing is this glsdb can become the most long range ammunition of the ukrainian army it will be able to hit target at a distance of km with a deviation of only meter if of course you take the word of it creator if this happens then the entire territory that the russian army control today in the dpr lpr zaporozhye and kherson region will be under the gun also under the threat of shelling will be the northern crimea and the border region with ukraine belgorod rostov bryansk and kursk well how doe glsdb work now you will understand why the projectile wa called smart it launch is carried out along a ballistic trajectory after launch the munition is climbed to the maximum height and then begin to plan for the enemy s object moreover the projectile can hit target in any direction even the opposite of the launch on the final trajectory the munition can adjust the direction of flight which allows it to be effectively used to destroy hard to reach target for example hidden behind hill or multi storey building before the explosion the projectile usually fall steeply downwards the explosion can also be carried out over the target to defeat infantry with a direct hit to destroy armored vehicle or with a delay this method is used to break through shelter the warhead of the glsdb is kg diameter is cm length is cm here you need to know that the price of glsdb consists of the cost of the already mentioned gbu bomb used a a warhead this is the cost of a rocket engine and the cost of assembly work and this is not le than it come out together with per unit and do you think that the ten of thousand of glsdb already promised to kiev will be given for so there are no fool in the white house or the pentagon for all these ammunition a well a for other weapon and military equipment zelensky and his government or rather the people of ukraine will have to pay no money no problem washington ha already come up with a great barter kiev will be paid by more furry enterprise mine say with reserve of titanium and uranium ore explored underground gas lake and even giant fat black earth expanse oh well let the fooled ukrainian have a headache about it and for u a new headache is much more important how we will fight this new scourge in the form of glsdb the thing is serious i will try to reassure my fellow citizen the antidote for such weapon apparently should be a modified version of the pantsirya sm complex after refinement taking into account the combat experience already gained in ukraine it wa able to deal with various type of complex target including small sized guided bomb how it will actually be svo will show although our army ha other way to avoid trouble from glsdb to destroy the american launcher himars and m from which the ammunition will be launched immediately after the appearance on the territory of ukraine and of course beat the warehouse with glsdb the inevitable question is do we have something like this eat this is a whole brood of high precision guided munition krasnopol kitolov gran and others the krasnopol guided projectile for example ha a semi active laser homing head designed to defeat stationary and moving armored and unarmored target and engineering structure at a distance of up to km and with the first shot edge and kitolov also ensure the defeat of not only stationary but also moving target with the first shot without additional shooting but we must admit that all these our high precision shell although they hit the enemy with sniper are still much inferior to the american glsdb in term of target range our design bureau and research institute are now working on this in the meantime we are more than parrying the glsdb capability with other instrument high precision kalibr kinzhal iskander missile and x aircraft missile and they hit not or kilometer but thousand or more listen a well colonel baranets the united state is preparing ukraine for a general battle in the spring more the court of ulyanovsk each army facing significant loss while managing only negligible gain both side have been readying for heavier ground combat with moscow pressing it goal to capture the entire donbas region of eastern ukraine and kyiv aiming to drive russian troop out of the country completely the russian approach shifted last month after the kremlin named gen valery v gerasimov to take over it struggling war home because of everything ksenia novikova a dancer from kyiv now living and working in the hague said in a recent phone interview but now we are kind of established here we have some work some tour and our kid have a more or le normal life it wa almost a year ago that russia invaded ukraine since then more than civilian have been killed and million displaced or like novikova and her family forced into exile on the first morning of the invasion novikova wa shaken out of bed by a deafening sound a military plane had crashed near her home on the outskirt of kyiv my previous life ended at that moment she told me last summer in the hague a tidily beautiful city near the coast where i had gone to report on the life of dancer in the united ukrainian ballet an ad hoc assemblage of refugee dancer from all over that country the company began to take shape last march through the effort of the dutch dancer igone de jongh and ha toured the netherlands and traveled to london australia and singapore this week starting wednesday it will make it united state debut at the kennedy center in washington in alexei ratmansky s staging of the th century classic giselle elizaveta gogidze one of three dancer cast in the title role said she wa excited to get acquainted with american culture i would like to show of course a ukrainian ballet to american audience she said and remind them with the help of ukrainian ballet art about the terrible war which ha been going on for almost a year on the eve of their american journey i checked in with ratmansky and some of the dancer i had met last summer to talk about how their life had taken shape in the month since i had seen them ratmansky who is of mixed russian and ukrainian background and grew up in kyiv ha been working with the company on and off in the hague since june both a a choreographer and a an adviser to de jongh with whom he had worked when she wa a star at the dutch national ballet it ha been a powerful experience for ratmansky who life in new york and who it wa recently announced is to become choreographer in residence at new york city ballet working with the ukrainian dancer is part of what he feel is a mission to demonstrate that ukrainian are fighting on all field including cultural he said in a recent interview i am supporting them with all my heart he said of the dancer i just feel i need to do it ratmansky s version of the ghost story giselle is both familiar and unfamiliar with surprising nuance he ha gleaned from archival source most strikingly a hopeful ending in place of the usual bleak one in addition to giselle he ha given the company permission to perform his recent dance for pacific northwest ballet wartime elegy set to music by the contemporary ukrainian composer valentin silvestrov who wa himself forced to flee ukraine by the war and ukrainian folk music the company will perform it in march a part of a triple bill that also includes ballet by jiri kylian and the duo paul lightfoot and sol le n who have been rehearsing with the company for many of these dancer it is their first introduction to collaborating with internationally recognized contemporary choreographer an experience that gogidze said would help to enrich ukrainian ballet culture once they return home when i heard i would be able to work with alexei ratmansky i said of course i want to be part of it it ha made me a better dancer i want to bring something new to ukrainian ballet from europe gogidze who joined the company in june is planning despite the danger to return to kyiv and to her home company the national ballet of ukraine where ratmansky too began his dancing career after the tour to washington the national ballet is active again though performance are often interrupted by siren that send patron and performer scurrying into bomb shelter below ground of course it s not easy gogidze said but it s my theater and they have a lot of work now i m really proud of the people who are working there now veronika rakitina a former dancer in the national company said people really want to see ballet even if there are alarm it s like a small light in the dark for them some like gogidze have returned or plan to do soon others like the dancer stanislav olshanskyi have found work elsewhere in november olshanskyi joined miami city ballet where he recently debuted in balanchine s the nutcracker on instagram he post avidly about both the war and his new life in miami but most like rakitina and her boyfriend vladyslav detiuchenko a dancer with the kyiv modern ballet have opted to stay in the hague at least for now she arrived in april with the couple s cat boston detiuchenko came a few month later after receiving a special permit from the ukrainian ministry of culture to leave the country to promote ukrainian culture abroad men of fighting age are generally not allowed to go abroad the pair along with the other dancer have settled in the hague s former music conservatory the company s home since it founding the conservatory serf a dormitory kitchen laundromat and rehearsal space it ha all the basic but few comfort most sleeping area carved out of former classroom are shared a are bathroom the floor are cement and the donated furniture is worn if you re just here for a few day it s all right gogidze said but for a long time it s hard the conservatory building had been slated for demolition before it wa repurposed a a home for the dancer with the demolition date drawing near the company will move to a newer space a former rehabilitation center in the district of kijkduin close to the sea the odessa born christine shevchenko a principal dancer at american ballet theater who also will dance giselle in washington spent time at the conservatory last year it wa a little overwhelming she said but at the same time a soon a i started rehearsal i felt like i wa pretty much at home i had this sense of happiness that i wa there with these people from my country who are just like me standing with them and then there were the child several of the dancer had arrived in the hague with kid who played in the hall while their parent rehearsed matvei then the son of volodymyr tkachenko who teach company class a few time a week seemed to be everywhere at once including in rehearsal and onstage with the dancer now matvei and the other child are attending school in the hague he go to school and then after school we play football work on his homework and spend time together tkachenko said i think he is happy like the others tkachenko expressed gratitude that he and his son were safe that they had been received warmly by the resident of the hague and that he wa working and like all of them he worry about relative and friend back home including his parent whose house wa destroyed by a missile last year but who refuse to leave when asked what his hope were tkachenko said i don t think about tomorrow i think about today performance and tour like the show in washington give the daily ritual of dancing life a sense of purpose the world should not get used to this war novikova said we must remind everyone around the world that we are a peaceful nation that we have our culture and we deserve a right to exist no one deserves to be killed for that the network ha unique footage from the zone of a special military operation which give reason to admire the composure of the russian soldier the video show footage from a drone hunting for a fighter it look like this is the signalman who went to check on the damaged antenna this is often how ukrainian act one drone blow up equipment and the second guard when repairman appear in the next second the drone throw a grenade launcher shot at the fighter the explosion thunder the warrior fall and freeze on the ground then the drone operator hovers over his body for a few second and then descends to film the russian chevron on his jacket and the face of the defeated and at this moment the fighter come to life grab the drone on the fly and look into the camera the shooting end when the fighter with his tactical glove begin to break the screw of the soulless killer handsome a real russian bear and a real guide on how a soldier can escape from a drone that is going to drop a grenade reader will write on the network on the frame you can distinguish the feature of the warrior s face and two chevron on his chest with a bear and with a russian flag is it possible to survive in such situation old timer on the network give different advice do not move in open area and listen if you hear the sound of motor or notice a drone try to shoot it down with small arm many succeed and the enemy operator will try to protect his bird and find another target if the attack did start jump sharply away from the place of rupture and roll on the ground without stopping change direction do not stop until cover is found vog fragmentation grenade launcher shot explodes immediately upon impact on the ground f and rgd grenade with a delay of second the latter can be tried to be discarded if they fell side by side in a trench it is theoretically possible to escape from an offensive grenade rgd with a scattering of fragment up to meter from the defensive f with a zone of generation of fragment up to meter it is impossible even in theory so when a grenade explodes it is better to lie down in the lowland behind a tree or any other natural barrier the network suggested that two fighter could participate in the capture of the enemy drone at once like colleague studied the behavior of the cameraman who after throwing the vog each time descended to consider and shoot on camera his next victim close up military personnel decided to catch a bloodthirsty drone on a live bait when the drone descended to the soldier who fell to the ground another fighter ran up to him from the rear and knocked him to the ground with a blow of a branch listen a well one button is enough there are constitutional border of the donetsk people s republic within which we returned to greater russia but it is worth considering the threat posed by enemy shelling therefore we will have to push him further away from the constitutional border of the dpr so that he physically cannot reach u and taking into account the weapon that he will have at that time you can name the timing i wouldn t be kidding that tomorrow or the day after tomorrow everything will be fine and the enemy will calm down won t rest and we understand that and we still have many step to liberate the remaining part of ukraine and to protect the interest of our country russia in addition to shelling a huge huge problem for donetsk is water it s not there really it won t be until slavyansk is liberated after all water wa supplied from there to almost the entire donbas let s take it one step at a time the first thing kiev did when it all started wa the blockade this is their policy since an economic blockade a transport blockade all possible restriction they understood perfectly well that the water blockade would be very sensitive for u and they could do it because slavyansk from where everything is controlled wa under their control you see this is how our region wa built they were fed through an artificial canal the seversky donets he provided u with water and by blocking it a very big problem wa created how do you deal with this now the first thing we did on our part of course with support at the federal level wa to use the reservoir that we have including backup water pipeline were built there it s a lot of work to feed to transfer from one reservoir to another but they still can t provide for all of our need we have to turn off the water in the city this is a forced measure for u it s painful enough for all of u water is now supplied for hour once every day but even with such a limited regime we have almost exhausted the reservoir we are informed that a water pipeline is being built from the rostov region in order to first of all support our water supply regime and secondly to improve the situation a decision is made to lay a water pipeline from the don it s kilometer two line the military construction company is extending it in a fairly record time by april these two line should allow the expansion of the water supply schedule this will cover the need of donbas unfortunately no this is again a temporary measure that will allow u to wait for the moment when we will liberate slavyansk a well the ukrainian will destroy all the water infrastructure that is there without a doubt we have no illusion here but we have already done some work here we have already prepared the equipment in order to start restoring the water supply a soon a possible then you can breathe freely there s another nuance there further they will have the opportunity to block the water already on the territory of the kharkiv region so for u there is a need to liberate this territory and then donbas will be fully provided with water our military officer dmitry steshin who now life in donetsk wa very happy when the custom and border control between the dpr and the rostov region were canceled there wa hope that price in store would fall but this did not happen why yes we now have an administrative border not a state border but we can t remove the checkpoint why there is a big of the rostov region and spread across russia then it will be much more difficult to fight this therefore we control the departure from the territory of the republic and there are queue at the literally from monday and then with limited functionality people are forced to go to the rostov region to get the service they need and the price have something to do with it and all this left an imprint on the carrier if we evened out the issue on the legislation we had a different taxation system vat refund but the cost of transporting good for example a car that carry good from moscow to the rostov region or to the kuban make three walk a week and when the same carrier travel in u he can make one walk in a week that is the price for the same transportation service in the dpr is time human right watch hrw ha alleged the mine similar to those allegedly used by ukraine against civilian in donetsk were found near school and kindergarten the mine were fired into the city by rocket while it wa occupied by russian force between april and september of last year the ngo said in a report published on tuesday dispersed hundred at a time the soviet era pfm mine are distinctively butterfly or petal shaped device and are designed to maim rather than kill those unfortunate enough to step on them or pick them up the hrw team entered the city following russia s withdrawal in mid september and found the mine in nine location including a school and kindergarten and a hospital read more olga sukharevskaya west ignores evidence of ukrainian torture and use of prohibited weapon when making war crime claim healthcare worker said that more than civilian including at least five child were wounded by the mine around half of the injury led to amputation of the foot or lower leg with timed fuse and would explode without warning up to three day after being dispersed according to more than resident russian force attempted to warn local of the danger posed by the ukrainian mine cleared some of the explosive and transported victim to russia for treatment once the russian left izium demining duty were reportedly carried out by ukrainian troop use of such antipersonnel mine is prohibited under the mine ban treaty to which ukraine is a signatory the u and russia are not party to the treaty questioned by hrw the ukrainian government insisted that it abides by all of it international obligation but refused to comment on the type of munition it used in and around izium read more un demand investigation into russian pow execution video any use of antipersonnel region of sumy which sentenced an unidentified person to three year behind bar for failing to respond to the ongoing military call up amid the conflict with russia the mp said the case wa particularly concerning given the court s approach to the proceeding and the defendant s testimony about his medical examination the defendant who pleaded not guilty claimed that the examination by the military wa a mere formality and that the doctor had pronounced him healthy without actually examining him the would be recruit however insisted he wa not fit for service citing acute periarthritis in his knee nevertheless the court found the man guilty of evading mobilization during wartime and sentenced him to three year behind bar draft evasion under ukrainian law carry a maximum penalty of five year in latest flash point in a battle that moscow view a crucial for it push to seize the donbas region in the east ukraine s general staff said on sunday that it soldier had repelled attack on the small village of blahodatne and several other settlement in the area the statement came a day after russia s wagner group a private military company that ha conducted much of the fighting around bakhmut on moscow s behalf claimed that it force had captured blahodatne near a key supply line for ukrainian force blahodatne is under our control yevgeny prigozhin a russian businessman and the head of the soledar a salt mining town that russian force recently captured after week of intense fighting and a road that run north from the city of bakhmut the road serf a a crucial supply line for ukrainian force defending the city since the summer bakhmut ha become a focal point of the fighting in eastern ukraine and the target of moscow s most significant attack moscow aim to encircle bakhmut cut off it supply route and then force the city s defender to withdraw despite some recent success russia s progress in the campaign ha been grindingly slow and both side have sustained heavy casualty but since capturing soledar earlier this month russian force have stepped up shelling of the village just to the west of it including blahodatne many civilian have followed a directive from the government in kyiv to leave donetsk which is home to bakhmut and one of the two area that make up the donbas region civilian who have stayed remain vulnerable to shelling and artillery attack with dozen killed in recent week pavlo kyrylenko the head of donetsk s military administration said on sunday that five civilian had been killed a day earlier in the region almost a year after russia launched invaded ukraine both side are expected to launch renewed attack in the coming month a kyiv put to use the heavy weapon sent from ally and russia deploys the huge number of men it drafted last year amid warning that russian force were regrouping for an anticipated spring offensive ukraine s ally pledged new sophisticated weapon for the fight germany and the united state last week announced that they would send battle tank to ukraine a move that came after week of tense back channel negotiation between european and u s official but it may be month before the tank rumble across the battlefield britain s defense ministry said on sunday that the first ukrainian soldier had arrived in britain for training on the challenger tank that were promised earlier this month in a speech on saturday president volodymyr zelensky of ukraine expressed gratitude for the latest promise of military aid but said that his country s ally should still do more ukraine need long range missile in particular to remove this possibility of the occupier to place their missile launcher somewhere far from the front line and destroy ukrainian city with them he said in an overnight address the city of kherson in southern ukraine ha faced repeated strike in recent week on sunday shelling there killed at least three people and wounded six others including a nurse according to the regional military administration today the russian army ha been shelling kherson atrociously all day mr zelensky said in his nightly address residential building various social and transport facility including a hospital post office and bus station have been damaged two woman nurse were wounded in the hospital a of now there are report of six wounded and three dead russian force have shelled kherson on a near daily basis following their retreat from the city in november the northeastern city of kharkiv recaptured by ukraine in september ha regained much of it prewar population but at just mile from the russian border remains well within striking distance late sunday the regional governor said a russian missile strike on the city had killed at least one person and injured three there have been sign that russian force are regrouping for a possible new offensive that could once again threaten kharkiv ukrainian official have said that russian tank division that had been deployed in belarus had been diverted possibly a part of a buildup of force that could once again push into the kharkiv region but the kremlin ha set full control of the donbas where it ha held considerable ground since a it heavy loss among regular conscript than among wagner fighter the report said the russian ability to execute large scale rapid offensive on multiple ax this winter and spring is thus very questionable assault on the town of vuhledar just over mile south of bakhmut it sits at the intersection of the eastern front in the donetsk region and the southern front in the zaporizhzhia region a location that england club a belarusian champion holding up the silverware in triumph with the war in ukraine still a brutal reality but wimbledon where belarusian and russian player were banned in and may be again this year ha remained an outlier in professional tennis and increasingly in international sport aryna sabalenka born and raised to pound tennis ball into submission in minsk belarus wa free to play and win the australian open woman s single title a a neutral competitor even if there wa scant chance her victory would be greeted neutrally at home or by her country s president alexander lukashenko whom she know personally i think everyone still know i m a belarusian player and that s it sabalenka said on saturday night at a news conference a glass of champagne in hand and the daphne akhurst memorial cup glittering beside her she put her name on the trophy and secured her first grand slam woman s single title with a brilliant and bold performance anything le would not have sufficed against elena rybakina in their gripping corner to corner final that might have been better suited to a ring a the two six footer exchanged big blow for two hour and minute mash tennis crush tennis rip tennis smack tennis take your pick but something onomatopoeic seemed appropriate with all that power on display and what separated this match from many a tennis slugfest wa the consistent depth and quality of the punching high risk wa rewarded repeatedly on saturday a both finalist took big swing aiming close to the line and often hitting them rybakina finished with winner to unforced error sabalenka in what looked like the finest performance of her career finished with winner to unforced error she cranked up the quality after an erratic opening set and won the lion s share of the rally or maybe the tiger s share considering she had the animal tattooed on her left forearm at age to remind her to fight for every point my parent didn t know about this tattoo she told the tennis channel when they saw it the first time my dad wa laughing i don t know why but my mom didn t talk to me for one week five year later the tattoo remains but much ha changed her father sergey died in at age leaving sabalenka committed to achieving the dream he had for her to become no she ha already fulfilled his wish in double reaching the top spot in when the new single ranking are released on monday she will be back at no behind iga swiatek who still ha a large lead based on her terrific season but who ha lost to sabalenka and rybakina in the last two significant tournament sabalenka defeated her in november in the semifinal of the wta final the season ending tour championship in fort worth rybakina overpowered swiatek in the fourth round in melbourne on her way to the final swiatek the polish star who looked set to become a dominant no is instead struggling to adjust to her new status and facing increased competition at the top although she remains until proven otherwise the best woman s clay court player but on other surface sabalenka and rybakina last year s surprise wimbledon champion clearly pose a formidable threat with their aggressive return relatively flat groundstrokes and penetrating serf there were rare variation on saturday a drop shot winner from rybakina a few defensive lob and the occasional off speed backhand but for the most part it wa strength versus strength straight line power against straight line power the spectacle wa frequently breathtaking but you did not have to hold your breath for more than a few second the longest rally wa stroke and the average rally length wa just stroke it wa tennis reminiscent of the big serving high velocity duel between serena and venus williams it wa also a significant departure from last year s australian open where ashleigh barty ended a year single drought for the host country by winning the title putting her court craft and crisply sliced one handed backhand to work before shocking the tennis world and australia by retiring in march at age but barty now married to garry kissick and expecting their first child ha hardly avoided the australian open making numerous public appearance this year and walking onto rod laver arena before saturday s final with the akhurst memorial cup in hand i can honestly look myself in the mirror and say i gave everything to tennis but it gave me back so much more in return she said in a recent interview and all that really start from the people i wa surrounded with so much of my success is our success it genuinely is sabalenka could relate to that on saturday a she shared a post victory moment with her team and then watched from afar a her normally stoic coach anton dubrov put a white towel to his face and sobbed in the player box sabalenka said she had never seen dubrov cry and explained that last season in february a she struggled with the yip on her second serve and her confidence and reached a point where she could not even openly discus the problem dubrov offered his resignation there were moment last year when he said i think i m done and i think i cannot give you something else and you have to find someone else sabalenka said in an interview with nine network and i said no you re not right it s not about you we just have to work through these tough moment and we ll come back stronger her performance on saturday wa incontrovertible proof that they had succeeded with the help of a biomechanical expert but also sabalenka s own resilience she is this year and though she double faulted seven time in the final including on her first match point she also repeatedly shrugged off any jitter and the palpable concern of the big crowd and came up with ace or service winner on subsequent serf in the end she hit ace to rybakina s for sure it s not easy mentally rybakina said of sabalenka she didn t have a great serve last year but now she wa super strong and she served well for sure i respect that i know how year her victory with her strong russian connection wa not the outcome the tournament wa seeking either when it imposed it ban under pressure from the british government some ukrainian player continue to oppose russian and belarusian being allowed to compete at all on tour even a neutral the debate is about to intensify a the international olympic committee begin to push for russian and belarusian to be allowed to compete a independent athlete at the summer olympics in paris a move the ukrainian government strongly opposes and could respond to by withdrawing it own athlete but sabalenka after sitting out wimbledon where she reached the semifinal in is now a grand slam single champion in australia and wa feted with no apparent ambivalence by the australian open tournament director craig tiley and wa awarded her trophy in rod laver arena by billie jean king sabalenka s news conference wa full of question intended not to confront her directly but rather to probe the issue however you amazing the west cannot defend itself against it today remember the giparsonic missile dagger one such in ukraine pierced a soviet underground bunker designed to hit an atomic bomb so zircon is it marine counterpart the rocket rush at a speed of mach that is time faster than the speed of sound and at the same time still maneuver no air defense or missile defense system neither existing nor promising is able to keep track of such a target much le catch up with it and intercept it zircon carry kilogram of explosive enough to cause life threatening damage to any aircraft carrier at the same time kilometer of range is not the limit some source talk about thousand kilometer a the maximum range of destruction the rocket pas through the marching section at an altitude of kilometer where the air is thin and practically doe not resist this can significantly increase the range and speed of the missile and facilitates anti missile maneuver such characteristic allow our even small ship to feel superior when meeting with an entire enemy aircraft carrier group it s like with kalashnikov to reach ten pitcher who have only fist well who will run first the west understands this very well here is what the american edition of military watch magazine writes about the characteristic of the zircon missile among the most valuable characteristic of the zircon is it extreme speed which combined with high maneuverability and small radar cross section make it almost impossible to reliably protect against this missile by existing air defense system the zircon will help make up for the russian navy s lack of a large surface fleet and allow for relatively smaller ship such a the admiral gorshkov class frigate and even smaller corvette sized ship could pose a very serious threat to fleet consisting of much larger destroyer cruiser and aircraft carrier russian ship will be able to exploit the missile s range advantage it uniquely high survivability against air defense and the enormous damage that the pure kinetic energy of it strike can cause so with zircon we re just getting started the most interesting is ahead the general director of the plant in reutov spoke about the surface missile however the same is on the way for submarine underwater zircon also successfully passed the test launch from the underwater and surface position were made by the submarine severodvinsk hospital wa just his latest offering for ukraine s war effort since the war began nearly a year ago the church s meeting hall ha served a a de facto warehouse for good headed to ukrainian soldier much of which is packed into cardboard box bought from the u haul store across the street on this sunday box holding winter boot waterproof and insulated for wear in wet and muddy trench were stacked near who grew up in western ukraine and came to america in said it started when his twin brother tara a sergeant in an army paratrooper unit that is now in the city of bakhmut asked for help collecting desperately needed supply his congregation of just to people down from in the s ha raised hundred of thousand of dollar to buy good for ukrainian soldier in combat bandage tourniquet body armor food uniform and even drone the church and it fund raising effort are among the many cultural and economic connection between this area of northeastern pennsylvania and the war this used to be a big ukrainian neighborhood here said mark izak who at year old joke that he is part of the youth group at st vladimir s the church wa built because there wa a large immigrant community for coal mining and for manufacturing he and two of his sibling maria and daria helped make the food friday and saturday and ran the cash box a they sold meal in the church s meeting hall on sunday morning time ha passed on mr izak said the neighborhood is more industrial commercial at this point now so the church kind of stand alone most of the people who moved here have passed on and their kid got educated and moved away a the coal mine closed the defense industry moved in to fill some of the void just outside the county courthouse downtown a statue of the labor leader john mitchell pay tribute to the city s tradition of unionized labor which continues at a government owned ammunition factory just a couple block away the acre site sits between rail line and a street renamed for president biden who wa born in scranton in building where steam locomotive were once repaired worker churn out steel body for millimeter artillery shell which are filled with explosive at a plant in iowa and shipped to ukraine those same artillery shell which the pentagon is rushing to boost production of sixfold the defense industry keep a relatively low profile in the region with the tobyhanna army depot nearby a well a that s what s happening at a small warehouse on a bluff overlooking downtown about a dozen shrink wrapped pallet awaited pickup to begin their journey to a united nation office near ukraine s border they contained detailed replica of some of the russian munition that litter the landscape unexploded the company a small outfit called inert product ha contract with nato nation to build the harmless immediate said richard carrick the company s vice president of sale and since the invasion the need ha gotten a lot larger the company s next project is a bomb disposal robot that will help de miner myron constantly on the move the father of eight child unlocked his cellphone and showed text message from ukrainian soldier who were wearing clothes he had sent and eating food he had shipped since to suitcase he said it s for a round trip ticket and some people are making two trip a week to do this at the same time father myron ha bill to pay he started cutting the grass at the church himself sell for that we are always keeping hope we ll be ok the head of russian private military company pmc wagner group ha urged one of his arch critic military blogger igor strelkov to join his fighting in ukraine due to issue with his paper at that time the ukrainian authority who have charged strelkov with committing war crime and engaging in terrorist activity offered a reward of for his capture igor strelkov girkin is a veteran of several armed conflict and a former officer of russia s federal security service fsb in a year after quitting the fsb he became one of the most prominent commander in the self defense force of the donetsk people s republic in it conflict with kiev and served a the dpr defense minister for three month after the region declared it independence from ukraine after returning to russia he switched to blogging and commenting often openly criticizing the government and military leadership in november a panel of dutch judge in the hague found strelkov guilty of murder for his alleged role in the downing of malaysia airline flight mh over eastern ukraine in and sentenced him in absentia to life imprisonment strelkov ha admitted to feeling a moral responsibility for the death of the people on board but ha refused to admit direct involvement vladimir skobtsov donbas za u and god is with u this is the name of the program of the cycle non people you know it s been a year since the special operation ha been going on all this time a city without water a city of one million but we don t have an epidemic all our people are clean the object relative the song to your word donbas is behind u ha become truly nationwide and not only for donetsk resident for the whole of russia we are one family we are one people we are one big russia we are about donbas he did not bring anyone to his knee because he will never get up himself and what is behind them this poem is called my paradise i have such a happy opportunity to stay in my hometown and if i leave i will lose my pulse and anything i write will be untrue i don t want to offend anyone people leave for various reason someone ha child someone ha sick parent you can t blame them for that but there is also another category of people a they were called frightened patriot i want to quote bulgakov never run away with a rat run to the unknown from danger volodya you are a creative person and creative people tend to doubt such a stereotype yes tell me there were throw when faced with a choice whose side you are on at the very beginning of the tragic confrontation in the donbas there wa an obvious choice a lot of my fellow artist are on the other side and i wa told come on with u but here it is the motherland where my ancestor are buried people live here flesh from flesh and blood from blood here it is the blood of a murdered child and there are those who still say not everything is so unambiguous and i chopped up everything that wa on the other side just a cut off when there is a big fight what can be ambiguous we ll figure it out later in my homeland child and old people are being killed just because they live in donbas naturally i will be on their side and the formula of the russian world is a follows there is no other people s trouble the trouble is one for all this is how the russian people exist and i believe that we are not fighting with the ukrainian in any case we are not fighting the ukrainian people we fight demon here it seems is a man in a human shell and speaks russian language hardly pronouncing ukrainian word but in him sits this demon volodya you often perform in hospital and on the front line yes if you want to know something about the battle go to the hospital to visit the wounded fighter i remember the first military hospital in donetsk my statement and i m told you re going to walk through the recumbents by the inertia of a civilian i thought recumbent well the temperature is high i walk in and there are people lying there who basically go the wound are incredibly severe i see a man who ha no spine almost blown him away and he lie facing the wall and i understand that a an artist i have to lift my spirit i sing he extends his hand to me shake me and say thank you i say thank you he say no let s remove the pathos thank you for coming i he say am leaving i saw the eye of death and this same man he s a hard worker a miner say if i played everything back i would again go to defend my house these are our hero people who defend their homeland are saint you can t get mad you can t stumble you have to stay human the question is how to remain human the entire history of our great country teach this first of all literature alexander pushkin s key poem to the slanderer of russia he wa spat upon by his liberal contemporary for this poem and there it wa this we have not recognized the brazen will of the one in front of whom you trembled not knowing this poem our militiaman with bare hand with baton with hunting rifle did not recognize the brazen will of the one under whom the others trembled this is how a russian person behaves listening to volodya how much he resembles vladimir vysotsky and these day they were just celebrating the th anniversary of the poet s birth it resembles both in the manner of singing and in the energy of some kind and even with the timbre of the voice therefore we continue to ask such question volodya is vysotsky on our side you said that before the interview now tell me what that mean this mean that if vladimir semyonovich were alive he would be with u on our side absolutely this wa said by my friend the kingdom of heaven to him journalist andrei babitsky and i agree with him vysotsky is where the truth is and the truth is ours tell me more volodya when is the victory what date what month what doe your poetic flair suggest what song will you perform on victory day and we have no choice to win not to win it will be it will not be victory it will come for all group of troop here they are sorted and sent to serviceman performing combat mission in the zone of the svo we deliver mail we work every day seven day a week mail is constantly coming from dnipro ukraine a russian missile a long a a city bus wa nearing the end of a roughly mile flight it pound warhead armed to detonate on impact a it wa descending through a gray sky last saturday traveling at supersonic speed rostyslav yaroshenko wa watching tiktok video in his kitchen on the third floor at victory embankment a sprawling apartment complex in the central ukrainian city of dnipro six floor up yevgeniy botvynov had just curled up with his wife olha under a blanket trying to keep warm during yet another power outage on the other side of the building two couple had gathered in their kitchen on the fourth floor one of them warming a late lunch the other doting on their year old son it wa what pas for an ordinary saturday for ordinary ukrainian people these day in a place far from the front line of the war with russia but never fully at peace all day air raid warning were sounding forcing people to make calculation that have become habitual go to a shelter or stay home take the elevator or the stair most of the time life appears to be normal and then suddenly it doe not around p m on the th day of russia s full fledged war in ukraine an ordinary saturday turned extraordinary when the russian kh missile slammed into victory embankment more than apartment were instantly incinerated with nothing left but a column of swirling ash along the singed periphery some unit were sliced apart with almost surgical precision exposing the content of people s living room bathroom and kitchen to the open air a bowl of fruit sat unscathed on the table in one kitchen that had been opened up like a dollhouse in another unit a painting of a dog hung crookedly on a kitchen wall though the kitchen wa no longer there on thursday the authority raised the death toll to including six child were wounded it wa one of the deadliest single attack against civilian since the early week of the war the apartment building an enormous soviet era edifice form a large inverted j that curl around an internal courtyard with the largest section facing the dnipro river an estimated people called it home the missile hit just above the joint where the building began to curve away from the embankment for those at the center of the impact death came instantly the explosion simply vaporized some resident according to the authority olha usova a year old dentist happened to be walking by on her way to a newly opened gym when the missile struck a single piece of shrapnel pierced her heart her husband eduard said killing her instantly he said he felt that with normal attack you had a decent chance of surviving just by remaining indoors this one wa different in this case he said such a rocket left no chance for survival many did manage to survive but that often depended on where in their home they were at the moment of impact many found themselves trapped the missile s force having sheared off the stairwell on two side of the building mr botvynov who had been cuddling with his wife under a blanket first had to pull himself free from the twisted remains of a balcony that had crashed through his living room then he grabbed his heavily bleeding wife and rushed to the front door when he opened it there wa nothing but a nine story drop into the smoking rubble below across the void he saw a woman curled in fetal position partly buried in debris from her destroyed apartment i thought that it wa a corpse said mr botvynov and then i see her waving her hand it is impossible to say whether the apartment complex in dnipro wa hit intentionally the kh is a s era anti ship missile launched by russian bomber that is designed to attack warship at sea and it may have more limited ability to accurately attack target on land a power station directly across the river from the complex could have been an intended target part of russia s strategy of starving ukrainian of electricity though it wa roughly two mile away the kremlin ha denied that a russian missile wa involved blaming an errant ukrainian air defense missile military expert have dismissed this claim a yet another russian fabrication pointing to the colossal damage the day of the attack wa a holiday in ukraine when many celebrate what is known a old new year based on the orthodox church s pre modern calendar that made olha afanasieva anxious after month of war ukrainian believe that the kremlin take a twisted pleasure in attacking on holiday for me it wa such an anxious day she said adding that she had insisted that her husband not go fishing a planned i felt like something wa about to happen m afanasieva s husband oleh valovyi took thing in stride though rocket had rained down on a number of city that day and the entire country wa under an alert for hour there are not that many bomb shelter mr valovyi said and you get tired of running there because the air raid alarm sound practically every day several time a day the couple were seated at their kitchen table when the missile hit she with her left side facing a window he directly in front of it the blast blew out the window and glass and debris shredded half of m afanasieva s face but her husband bore the brunt of it he wa just all black and bloody she said his face started to turn black under the eye and all that my god finding their apartment door jammed she went to the window screaming and waving a towel and a bathrobe trying to catch the attention of firefighter who had started assembling below at the same time mr botvynov facing the nine story drop with no stair wa frantically signaling with his cellphone s flashlight worried that his wife who wa bleeding profusely from her head would lose consciousness on the fourth floor kateryna zelenska who is and deaf wa trapped under the rubble unable to signal emergency worker her husband oleksii zelensky and their year old son mykyta were somewhere nearby but she did not know their condition slab of concrete had collapsed onto their apartment from the floor above somehow m zelenska managed to make a brief call to her mother apparently to say goodbye she said mom i love you i love you and that s it it broke off her mother oksana kulak said through tear over the next hour rescuer using crane and ladder saved dozen of people trapped on upper floor it took about three hour to reach mr botvynov and his wife m afanasieva got out first but said she regretted leaving her husband to manage by himself he passed out on the balcony a firefighter were trying to guide him onto a platform atop a ladder later at the hospital he wa in surprisingly good spirit for someone whose body had been pierced by glass head to toe but he expressed confusion over russia s choice of target i work at a company that deal with agriculture selling part for the tractor a completely peaceful profession he said surely my death would not have any military significance how rescuer noticed m zelenska the deaf woman is unclear but by sunday morning firefighter attached to safety line and standing on a platform suspended by a crane were working furiously at the spot where her apartment had been they cut away debris for hour finally she appeared covered in dust alive but visibly distressed for the next hour firefighter continued to hack at the concrete slab that had pancaked onto m zelenska s apartment searching for her husband and son by tuesday morning the couple s family had gathered at the site in what wa a mostly silent vigil until a the sun came up m zelenska s father mykola kulak vented his anger the russian let them all perish these devil he screamed holding up his phone to show a video of his grandson this child is still lying under the rubble i am cursing them and i wish that every russian family ha two or three just like this lying there like our child shortly afterward rescuer brought down the body first mykyta then oleksii using a special crane they were placed on the ground in black body bag a their family waited to carry out the wrenching task of identifying them oleksii s parent knelt in front of their son s body unzipped the bag and for several interminable minute caressed him sobbing m zelenska s parent had rushed off earlier to join their daughter who had been hospitalized since being rescued two day earlier she had found out on the internet that the body of her husband and son had been recovered the first confirmation she had that they were dead on tuesday afternoon the authority declared an end to the search but by evening firefighter had returned to victory embankment for an unexpected rescue mission one that came at the behest of rostyslav the boy who had been watching tiktok video before the missile hit he had managed to escape his mangled apartment by climbing out a window and scrambling down the building s facade with the help of bystander but in the confusion he had been unable to locate his white cat belyash i wa more frightened for my cat he said and so firefighter once again climbed into the building a rostyslav his mother nadiia and a small crowd of onlooker gathered in the darkness below after about minute a firefighter emerged from the kitchen window a red and of artyomovsk called bakhmut by ukraine the capture of the village is vital to the russian operation to encircle artyomovsk which is a major stronghold and logistics hub for ukrainian force in the little combat experience to defend artyomovsk read more kiev sent poorly equipped troop to defend key donbas city the time if russian force manage to seize the city it would have serious consequence for kiev the bnd warned adding that control over artyomovsk would potentially facilitate major russian advance deeper into ukrainian held territory the city of artyomovsk ha become a stronghold of the ukrainian army in the year since the coup in kiev it is part of a kilometer long defense line created by the ukrainian force during the intervening year russia claim sovereignty over the city along with the rest of the donetsk people s republic which joined russia in october after a referendum kiev rejected the vote a a sham the city remains a major logistics hub for ukrainian force in the region and ha emerged a a focal point of the conflict for both side in recent month russian troop have achieved several victory in the area over the last several week taking the city of soledar and the strategic village of klescheevka among several other settlement a they seek to encircle artyomovsk the pentagon ha announced that it will send stryker armored fighting vehicle to ukraine the first such transfer of the versatile eight wheeled weapon from u s military stockpile to a foreign country the strykers will be joined by bradley infantry fighting vehicle and other weapon a part of a billion military aid package for kyiv combined with the bradley announced for ukraine on jan the package will give kyiv the equivalent of two armored brigade worth of vehicle according to a statement emailed to reporter thursday evening according to the u s army there are different variant of the stryker some are built primarily to move infantry soldier in and out of battle while others are designed to carry weapon like millimeter mortar to provide fire support others carry medium and large caliber weapon for direct fire on enemy troop with millimeter cannon or even larger millimeter gun strykers were initially built with flat bottomed hull which proved vulnerable to improvised bomb set to detonate underneath them by insurgent in iraq in response the army phased those vehicle out with newer strykers fitted with a v shaped bottom similar to those used on mine resistant ambush protected vehicle which are also called mraps exactly which version or version will be provided to ukraine is unclear u s army leader decided in the s that the service needed a more mobile strike force that could go anywhere in the world in just four day that meant they needed a vehicle that wa well armed and armored while still relatively lightweight and small enough to be carried by a c cargo plane the stryker wa chosen a the vehicle the army could build that force around they first saw combat in iraq in strykers are le heavily armored than bradley and at to ton they weigh far le than the bradley which can weigh a much a ton according to a report from the congressional research service while bradley run on tread which offer excellent traction over uneven terrain strykers run on eight wheel which can still function even if they have been hit with bullet or shrapnel strykers are also much faster than bradley capable of speed of mile per hour according to the congressional report the stryker can also be configured in a number of different variant including some for use by engineer or a ambulance the pentagon s announcement thursday said that the strykers would also be provided with mine roller wheeled sled that are designed to be heavy enough to trigger anti vehicle land mine and are pushed ahead of armored vehicle in the hope of clearing safe path through minefield a the war between ukraine and russia ha evolved into a more static battle between entrenched soldier protected by belt of anti tank land mine the combination of strykers with mine roller and additional demolition equipment for what the pentagon referred to a obstacle clearing indicates that the united state is providing ukraine with specific capability intended to enable kyiv s armed force to break though russian defense in the course of performing task in the territory of the troitsky and svatovsky ulyana got the diary of a mobilized doctor who picked up a cat on the front line and told how he served with him diary of a mobilized doctor well friend my name is ignatius and i am from the city detsovska i think it s understandable why i m distorting the name and the city by profession i am a resuscitation doctor the military department is behind him which is why he received a summons october october i m there the wounded are brought here to provide pre hospital care a lot of wounded blood pain and the tool to put it all away resident of the city that have come under fire are also brought to me medicine and equipment are few we give our best we sleep for hour oct it s a tough night i don t have the strength there is only one small joy we got a cat damn he know where he s from here there s not much left alive around but this little friend is now like a piece of normal life for me if they throw it to another place i will ask to take it with me i ve never had anything alive in the house other than fish a a child somehow they did not start and then i wa afraid that i would not cope because i wa always at work and now i realize i m an idiot it s more likely that they care about u than we care about them they entertain when there are heavy thought in the head warm the soul lying on the chest and most importantly cause love and kindness kindness is lacking when you see all these injury a lump of hatred creep up to your throat then you see the same suffering in the prisoner and the hatred is a little different and then you stroke that fluffy face and all the hatred go away october october the position are quiet i can t decide what to call the cat he s still just a cat it seems to be the calmest and happiest creature in this location i m being thrown to the frontier medical station in the rear it is necessary to replace the doctor who suffered a heart attack you can even sleep there sometimes the cat is coming with me who need him here i don t want him to escape fortunately it is so tame i threw it by the sinus and drove off he basks there in my big military jacket and no special cell are needed while driving i wa very overwhelmed with excitement or longing at one point i caught myself thinking that i wanted to stay in the ravine we were passing by only pity for the cat and of course thought about the daughter held back you can still live for these two october october the cat and i are there i m already substituting for a colleague in the morning i managed to get some rest i lay down and instantly fell into a half sleep half fog the firing range the tank the explosion i woke up and realized that i wa no longer in bed but in a ravine i hear a burst of gunfire and a deafening volley i can t feel my leg and i m scared to look there i overpower myself look at my foot and realize that my cat my only friend the remnant of my soul my sympathy my kindness lie on them lie torn i woke up again to my own scream groping the cat that wa basking next to me under my jacket the dream wa realistic two day have almost passed in the evening the cat and i will go back october october i drink coffee and go for the second day i slept for a couple of hour it s that i m already losing my focus of vision i asked to be replaced i m going to rest the location is cold there is nothing to heat yet the cat sleep around the clock in my blanket so the place is always heated for me he only get up when i come back and feed him he eats the same thing a me semi dry porridge bread broth what they will bring in general he doesn t complain good cat if he and i had lived i would have brought him home my daughter would be happy after the shelling the day before yesterday he lost two colleague oct appendicitis that s what i wasn t expecting i thought anything could happen to me but appendicitis now probably i will be sent to the hospital for we do not have the condition for this operation here oct i ve gotten a little smaller i m lying down for the first time in year i lie down and do not do a damn thing i forgot to tell of course i could not leave the cat on the battlefield he begged his roommate to look after him but he watched the wounded all day since i wa supposed to be transported to a hospital in an ordinary russian city i thought that the best option wa to take the cat with me driving through the suburb of donetsk i stopped at a pet store and bought him a carrier and a collar naturally we couldn t take a cat to the hospital sterility and all that so while i wa waiting for the operation i agreed with the guard that he would keep him in his back room feed him give him a drink for loyalty i gave more tip tomorrow a father and daughter will come to see me they ll take him in of course i ll be lonely without him so attached to this snot fluffy but he ll be better off that way and my daughter ha been begging for a cat for a long time october november my father and daughter came to see me at the hospital i don t know how much i ve changed this month i ve learned a lot from their face i gave the cat away there wa a lot of joy for both the family and the cat he s a bit skittish because of where he originally wa but i think he ll get used to a quiet home life quickly after a noisy front line to get into a warm calm house is like winning the lottery november on the road now without a cat eh today i am already stepping in for a day november i wa about to take my shift when the soldier dragged a wounded dog source telegram channel diary mobilized reader can discus the article on the author s ukraine is ready for a dialogue with russia but only if it is based on universal principle of international law said the press secretary of the ukrainian leader sergei nikiforov kyiv ukraine when the blare of the siren rang out over the loud speaker the student in a school in central kyiv quickly rose from their desk packed their thing and filed calmly down the stair behind their teacher but this wasn t a drill amid the darkness huddled in the narrow hallway of their basement shelter student chatted among themselves some used the light on their smartphones to continue working on classroom assignment they would remain in the shelter for nearly two hour until the threat of a potential airstrike passed it is the new reality for the schoolchildren age to who still attend class in person at this large public elementary and high school in ukraine s capital although class resumed in september a relentless barrage of russian strike targeting the city since october ha crippled the country s power grid caused rolling blackout in kyiv and offered the latest challenge to education during wartime we hope this will not last for a long time said olena romanova who ha been the principal of the school for the last decade we also have a generator but since the school is large it cannot meet the need of the entire institution initially the school struggled to adapt and some student grade faltered she said but the school is doing it best to adapt to the new obstacle school across the ukrainian capital have shuttered for january amid ongoing power cut and m romanova said teacher have been offering extra lesson online to try to keep student up to speed but a visit to one school in the city in late december before the winter break offered a window into the hardship these child need to overcome and their determination to continue on with parent and teacher doing what they can to provide the kid with some sense of normalcy there are normally child enrolled in this school but in december some class were only half full a many student are opting to study online and some parent believe it s safer for their child to study from home some student are living abroad after fleeing alongside million of other ukrainian but continue to dial into class on the flip side some new student have joined the classroom displaced from battered community closer to the front line in ukraine s east the school requested that it exact name be withheld for security and privacy reason but few aspect of the education process are untouched by the war with russian strike a constant threat high school student receive first aid training at school during last month s visit a group of high school girl practiced applying tourniquet and bandage on one another for now though the blackout remain the most pressing concern the school s generator is limited to how much power it can provide m romanova said it s enough for online class it s enough to keep the light and internet on she said but it s not enough to run the school cafeteria since it u electric stove and the generator isn t powerful enough for them a the power went out the hungry student at the school were disappointed when the chef olena sulyma told them that the food hadn t arrived yet she ha been working in this cafeteria for year but lately she ha had to get more creative in how she provides hot meal for the hundred of student here amid the power outage she and chef at other school nearby that have similar energy issue have been partnering with another local school where there is still electricity they can cook the meal there and then bring them to their own school ukrainian are inventive with thing that bother u that s why our school chef try to adapt m romanova said so we adapted and it s not an issue at the moment the kid are always full despite the hardship many of the student prefer to be in school one girl taisia said she prefers to be alongside her classmate even if it meant regular trip to the basement shelter i can t stay at home alone she said but when there is an air alarm and i m in school at first i feel calm but then when i see in the news that something is approaching i feel uneasy and we go to shelter their parent become unsettled a well while this particular school ha not been targeted a number of educational institution across ukraine have been when the siren go off warning of the potential for an incoming strike many parent rush to pick their child up from school more than educational institution had been damaged by bombing and shelling by the last week of december according to data from the ukrainian ministry of education and another were completely destroyed maria lavrynenko is still opting to study online from her home because of her family s safety concern maria fled the city with her parent early in the war relocating to a village farther west from there she continued her education online and chose that option when they returned to their home this fall each day maria who is in the th grade log on from her family s apartment in kyiv at a m and continues with her lesson until p m then she attends lesson at a rhythmic gymnastics school and hope to study physical education at university but rolling power outage have forced her to find creative way to complete her assignment when the light flicker off for me it is very difficult to study because sometimes there is no electricity and i need to boost my knowledge she said adding that she is preparing for her final exam later this year sometimes she head to a nearby store that ha a generator and wi fi and electricity available on a recent afternoon a the power at home cut out she took a photograph of an essay she had just completed and sent it to her teacher using the mobile internet on her phone sometimes she drop off her assignment in person still she and her family think it s best for her to study from home there are also other reason for distance learning her mother maia lavrynenko explained when there is an air alert in school everyone go to the shelter and when you are at home you can continue to study even during the air alert staying at home is no guarantee of tranquillity giggled in their onesies the older student also held a holiday party and shared snack and tea m romanova the principal said it is important for her to maintain this positivity for in person schooling they stated that there are good orthodox christian who are for them for progress but then they were also eliminated and then the church is liquidated the ukrainian authority do not see christianity a of god perun odin yarilo and what is neopaganism it differs from the traditional one in that it is completely fictional it is based on fantastic work that are passed off a historical source the same to create a civilization on the planet we also had this but thank you they did not allow u to enter university or school and they allowed it a a result in ukraine pseudohistory eventually became the shelling of city and town near the front line but image of the devastation in the central city of dnipro provoked anger and despair among ukrainian and the attack appeared to be part of a return unclear over the weekend russia launched dozen of missile at city across ukraine in two wave of strike that coincided with the orthodox new year and shattered the relative calm of recent day the missile that struck the building in dnipro appeared to have been a kh cruise missile also known a an x missile according to hanna maliar ukraine s deputy minister of defense she said it wa one of five of them fired at ukrainian territory that day the soviet era missile weigh about pound can be fired from long distance and are intended for anti ship operation they are also capable of carrying nuclear warhead ukraine s prosecutor general s office said the kh missile that appears to have hit dnipro could have been launched by only one russian unit the nd guard heavy bomber aviation regiment this type of missile lead to the greatest human casualty because the missile is extremely inaccurate the office said therefore the use of such weapon for target in densely populated area is clearly a war crime more than missile of that type have been used in attack on ukrainian territory since russia invaded including a strike on a shopping center in kremenchuk in june that killed people immediately after the dnipro attack pro russian news outlet and influential military blogger claimed that the apartment building wa not the target but had been struck by fragment of the missile after ukrainian air defense tried to intercept it but ukrainian force were quick to deny that and the evidence from the scene pointed to a direct strike on the building the armed force of ukraine have no weapon capable of shooting down this type of missile m maliar said in fact she said the attack showed the need for antiaircraft missile system like the patriot system that ukraine ha long been lobbying it ally for the united state and germany have agreed to supply ukraine with the patriot system and ukrainian force are to begin training on it in oklahoma in the coming week dnipro a city nestled against the river of the same name had a population of just under one million before the war began after moscow invaded it wa targeted by russian shelling but never occupied by it force and there are no more in the world a if they were garbage said the museum s longtime director alina dotsenko who recently returned from exile recounting what employee and witness had told her when she ravaged ukraine with deadly missile strike and brutal atrocity on civilian it ha also looted the nation s cultural institution of some of the most important and intensely protected contribution of ukraine and it forebear going back thousand of year international art expert say the plundering may be the single biggest collective art heist since the nazi pillaged europe in world war ii in kherson in ukraine s south ukrainian prosecutor and museum administrator say the russian stole more than piece of fine art and one of a kind artifact they dragged bronze statue from park lifted book from a riverside scientific library boxed up the crumbling year old bone of grigory potemkin catherine the great s lover and even stole a raccoon from the zoo leaving behind a trail of vacant cage empty pedestal and smashed glass ukrainian official say that russian force have robbed or damaged more than museum including several in kherson which wa retaken in november and others in mariupol and melitopol which remain under russian occupation with ukrainian investigator still cataloging the loss of missing oil painting ancient stele bronze pot coin necklace and bust the number of reported stolen item is likely to grow the plundering is hardly a case of random or opportunistic misbehavior by a few ill behaved troop ukrainian official and international expert say or even a desire to turn a quick profit on the black market instead they believe the theft are a broadside attack on ukrainian pride culture and identity consistent with the imperial attitude of russia s president vladimir v putin who ha constantly belittled the idea of ukraine a a separate nation and used that a a central rationale for his invasion it s not like one soldier putting a silver chalice in his rucksack said james ratcliffe general counsel of the art loss register a london based organization that trace stolen art this is a far far larger scale at one museum in melitopol a southern ukrainian city that the russian seized in the first day of the war witness said that a mysterious man in a white lab coat had arrived to carefully extract with glove and tweezer the most valuable object from the collection including gold piece from the scythian empire crafted year ago a he lifted out the priceless antiquity a squad of russian soldier stood firmly behind him in case anyone should try to stop him in each case of looting witness including caretaker security guard and other museum employee who said they had been pressured or forced to help reported a centrally controlled expert led operation shocked is not the word i am furious oleksandr tkachenko ukraine s culture minister said in a broadcast interview a he toured the looted kherson art museum visibly upset if they stole our heritage they believe that we wouldn t continue to live and to create but we will the ukrainian have a lot of battle on their hand town in the east like bakhmut are being pummeled drone swarm continue to take out critical infrastructure plunging thousand into the dark vast swath of territory in the south and east remain occupied and one out of three ukrainian ha been forced to flee from home but even with the war raging a group of ukrainian lawyer and art expert are working day and night to collect evidence for what they hope will be future prosecution of cultural crime from dimly lit office in frosty building with no power or heat wearing glove and woolly hat indoors they make meticulous list of missing object comb through museum record and try to identify potential witness and local collaborator who might have helped the russian steal the ukrainian are also working with international art organization like the art loss register to track the looted piece everyone in the art market is on red alert to look out for this material mr ratcliffe said every auction house that see material from ukraine is going to start asking a lot of question his organization he said ha already registered more than item from ukraine believed to have been stolen and others at risk including painting from kherson s art museum and scythian gold from melitopol the ukrainian accuse the russian of breaking international treaty that outlaw art looting such a the convention for the protection of cultural property in the event of armed conflict created in the wake of world war ii the treaty call for signatory to prohibit prevent and if necessary put a stop to any form of theft of cultural property both ukraine and russia signed it but the russian have flipped the narrative and presented their action not a theft but liberation don t panic said kirill stremousov kherson s russia installed deputy administrator when he explained in october what had happened to the statue that disappeared from kherson he said that when the fighting stopped the monument would definitely return and that everything wa being done for the benefit of preserving the historical heritage of the city of kherson the statue have yet to be returned and a few week later just a ukrainian troop were liberating kherson mr stremousov wa killed in a suspicious car crash many of the painting looted from the kherson art museum including beloved
